Award.AbstractNarration:
How does the brain decide when it is time to work to obtain food or put its effort into finding a mate? What changes in the brain to assign priorities to specific rewards depending on the internal state of the animal? In these experiments, the investigators will study how the hormone, estradiol, acts in the brain of the female rat to decrease food intake and the motivation for food, while enhancing reproductive motivation. The investigators will study the chemistry of the brain as it responds to the presentation of a cue that has been previously paired with a reward. These studies will investigate how changes in the neurotransmitter, dopamine, is affected by reward-related cues under different hormonal states. These results will enhance the understanding of the role of hormones to influence motivation and decision making processes, and will contribute to the understanding of neuroplasticity in general.

In the female rat, estradiol decreases food intake and the motivation for food while enhancing female reproductive motivation. Further, dopamine (DA) increases in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) upon the presentation of a cue that has been previously paired with a reward, and NAc DA is implicated in attribution of incentive salience for that reward. How DA signaling is affected by reward-related cues under different hormonal states, and the mechanism through which estradiol affects the incentive salience of these cues, is critically important to our understanding of motivation in the female rat. Experiments will use fast scan cyclic voltammetry to measure spontaneous DA release in the core and shell of the NAc during responding for a mate or food under different hormone conditions, using our novel paradigm to quantify female reproductive motivation. The role of DA in mediating the switch from choosing food to choosing a mate in the female will be determined. Graduate students and undergraduates will be involved in these studies. Findings will be disseminated through scientific publications as well as presentations at conferences at the local and national level. Specific activities for students in the laboratory included pre/post assessment of laboratory skills and development of a BrainsRule! presentation to local and Detroit middle school students about the neural mechanisms of motivation and choice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sex differences in motivated behaviors have evolved due to sex-specific adaptive pressures. Importantly, the neural circuitry underlying motivation is regulated by ovarian hormones in females, but not in males. This is important for the coordination of motivated behaviors which change with the reproductive state in females in order to enhance their reproductive success.

Ovarian hormones reach the brain and regulate release of the neurotransmitter, dopamine. This means that dopamine-mediated motivated behaviors are regulated to enhance adaptive choices and motivation for food vs a mate.

In this project we established that acute treatment with the ovarian hormone estradiol enhances the effect of cocaine on phasic dopamine release within the nucleus accumbens of females, but not males (Fig 1A). We went on to demonstrate that the effects of estradiol seen here are regulated by activation of the specific estradiol receptor (ER) subtype, ERb. The ERβ selective agonist diaryl propionitrile (DPN), but not the ERα selective agonist propyl pyrazole triol (PPT), was able to recapitulate the effects of estradiol on dopamine release following cocaine administration (Fig 1B).

This work further clarifies the role of estradiol in regulating dopamine release but does not indicate the behavioral significance of ovarian hormones acting within this circuitry. Accordingly, we next sought to determine whether administration of estradiol and progesterone in a regimen that induces sexual receptivity and increases sexual motivation could also reduce motivation for food.

We found that ovarian hormones attenuate motivated responding for a palatable food reward, but only after administration of both estradiol and progesterone (Fig 2A), indicating the effects of ovarian hormones on motivation for food are dissociable from their effects on consummatory feeding behavior and drug-induced dopamine release.

We then tested whether the effect of progesterone on motivation for food was mediated by a direct effect on dopamine circuitry. We administered the progesterone receptor antagonist RU-486 selectively to the nucleus accumbens of females while simultaneously administering estradiol and progesterone to induce sexual receptivity. We found that blockade of progesterone receptors within the nucleus accumbens was not sufficient to prevent the ovarian hormone mediated decrease in motivation for food, but did increase motivation for food when given in the absence of ovarian hormones.

Finally, we tested whether the effects of ovarian hormones on motivation for food are mediated by the same receptor mechanism as the effects of estradiol on cocaine induced dopamine release. Toward this aim, we tested whether selective activation of ERα, ERβ, or G-protein coupled estradiol receptor-1 (GPER-1) in combination with progesterone could replicate the effects of estradiol benzoate on motivation for food. We found that activation of the ERα selective agonist PPT followed by administration of progesterone reduced motivation for food, but this change in motivation did not follow the same temporal pattern that occurred following administration of estradiol benzoate and progesterone administration of the non-selective agonist estradiol benzoate (Fig 2B).

We then examined whether ovarian hormones act to increase motivation for sex but decrease motivation for food in order to facilitate adaptive choice when females are sexually receptive. We found that administration of estradiol and progesterone not only decreased motivation for food and enhanced motivation for a mate when both rewards were available (Fig 3), but also biased a female?s choice for food vs access to a sexually experienced male conspecific.

Taken together, these findings propose a potential explanation for why dopaminergic circuitry underlying motivated behaviors is responsive to ovarian hormones, providing an adaptive interpretation of a mechanism that is most commonly investigated within the context of maladaptive and disordered behaviors.
